information_requirement: Is an adversary using GUI-based remote access for execution on ICS hosts? (PIR)

evidence.description: A successful remote interactive logon (RDP) to a critical ICS host, such as an HMI or Engineering Workstation, from an anomalous source or at an unusual time.
evidence.nai: Human-Machine Interfaces (HMIs), Engineering Workstations (EWS), Operator Workstations (OWS), ICS Domain Controllers
evidence.action: Filter Windows Security logs for Event ID 4624 where Logon Type is 10 (RemoteInteractive). Establish a baseline of authorized user accounts and source workstations that legitimately use RDP to access critical ICS assets. Alert on any logon event that deviates from this baseline, such as a logon from an unapproved source IP, a user account not associated with engineering or operations, or a logon occurring outside of standard maintenance windows. Calculate the frequency of RDP sessions per user/source and flag users with a statistically significant increase in session frequency (e.g., > 95th percentile of their historical activity).

evidence.description: Network traffic indicating an RDP or VNC session to a critical ICS asset from an unauthorized source or with unusual characteristics (e.g., long duration, high volume).
evidence.nai: ICS Network Segments, Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) Firewalls, Connections between IT and OT networks
evidence.action: Continuously monitor Zeek conn.log for connections to destination ports TCP/3389 (RDP) and TCP/5900-5906 (VNC). Create an allow-list of authorized source-destination IP pairs for these services within the ICS environment. Generate an alert for any connection that does not match the allow-list. For allowed connections, establish a baseline for session duration and bytes transferred. Use statistical analysis (e.g., z-score, interquartile range) to detect sessions that are outliers in terms of their duration or data volume, which could indicate interactive adversary activity rather than routine access.
